abstract: Ontong Java Plateau (OJP) is a huge, completely submerged volcanic edifice that is hypothesized to have formed during large plume melting events ∼90 and 120 My ago. It is currently resisting subduction into the North Solomon trench. The size and buoyancy of the plateau along with its history of plume melting and current interaction with a subduction zone are all similar to the characteristics and hypothesized mechanisms of continent formation. However, the plateau is remote, and enigmatic, and its proto-continent potential is debated. We use SS precursors to image seismic discontinuity structure beneath Ontong Java Plateau. We image a velocity increase with depth at 28±4 km consistent with the Moho. In addition, we image velocity decreases at 80±5 km and 282±7 km depth. Discontinuities at 60–100 km depth are frequently observed both beneath the oceans and the continents. However, the discontinuity at 282 km is anomalous in comparison to surrounding oceanic regions; in the context of previous results it may suggest a thick viscous root beneath OJP. If such a root exists, then the discontinuity at 80 km bears some similarity to the mid-lithospheric discontinuities (MLDs) observed beneath continents. One possibility is that plume melting events, similar to that which formed OJP, may cause discontinuities in the MLD depth range. Plume–plate interaction could be a mechanism for MLD formation in some continents in the Archean prior to the onset of subduction.

author_highlights.sentence: SS precursors image negative seismic discontinuities at 80 and 282 km beneath OJP.
In context with previous results it may suggest a 282 km thick viscous root.
If a root exists, the 80 km discontinuity may be a mid-lithospheric discontinuity.
Large mantle melting events may form strong, sharp discontinuities.
Similarities suggest OJP may be analogous to the formation of continents.

body_text.sentence: Finally, xenoliths from the margins are consistent with a stable root structure related to anomalous mantle melting that extends to at least 120 km, i.e., deeper than the 80 km discontinuity (Tommasi and Ishikawa, 2014), implying that the 80 km discontinuity may not be the LAB.
